title: Woman left with £800 bill as PPI firms bombard people with £10-a-text rip off
text:

PPI claim firms are bombarding “clients” with texts costing up to £10 each – leaving people with bills totalling hundreds.

Complaints about the service soared as companies tried to cash in on a last-minute rush before the claim deadline.

Banks have so far paid out £55billion in compensation for the mis-sold payment protection insurance, creating a bonanza for claims management firms.

Retired civil servant Jill Rippon is facing an £800 bill after being sent 80 texts – sometimes as many as ten a day.

Jill, 64, had responded in June to an online pop-up advert by Allay Claims.

In the event, she signed up with ­another claims firm instead. But she was stunned when Allay Claims told her she would still have to pay its fees, including £10 for every text they sent.

Jill said: “It’s a licence to print ­money. It was over £800 in texts. They’ve got you over a barrel.”

Allay Claims, also known as checkmypaydayloan.com, told her the fees were listed in its terms and conditions.

Jill, of Dungeness, Kent, said: “I feel really angry – and annoyed with myself for not reading all the small print.

“What I don’t know is if they’ll now charge me for the texts on top of any commission if I ever win any compensation.”

(Image: Getty)

Claims firms promise to take the hassle out of searching for mis-sold PPI in exchange for a share of your payout if you win.

The Information Commissioner, Britain’s data regulator, says complaints about PPI texts soared five-fold in July, from the 20 it had 12 months earlier, up to 135.

Gripes shot up again in August – the month the deadline passed – from nine to 128. Watchdogs have condemned the nuisance texts as a scandal.

Martyn James, of complaint ­handling website Resolver, said: “It’s outrageous that claims managers are able to rip people off twice – once for a service that isn’t necessary, and then charging for nuisance messages.

“I’ve heard of £4 and £5 but £10 per text is outrageous. It’s a scandal, a form of harassment.”

Allay Claims said: “We do have the right to charge for work done, but only after a 14-day cooling off period.

“Clients are only liable for those messages if they cancel outside the cooling off period.”
description: EXCLUSIVE: Retired civil servant Jill Rippon was billed £800 for a service she did not use - including £10 for every text sent
